Configure Default Parameters

The 'Default Parameters' option on the CSP Web Gateway Management page provides you with a mechanism for maintaining the global (system-wide) configuration parameters for Caché Server Pages. Note that you must be a system manager to use this option.

The set of parameters that you establish with this option constitutes the global configuration for Caché Server Pages. This means that when you configure access to a particular Caché Server, any unspecified optional parameters and/or custom system forms are automatically inherited from the global configuration. For example, if you do not set a 'Server Response Timeout' parameter for a specific server, that server will inherit the global 'Server Response Timeout' setting.
The Default Parameters are made up of two components:
System parameters
Custom error messages

Event Logging Parameters

The 'Event Log Level' field is where you can control what information the CSP Gateway will write to the Event Log. Logging options are defined as a string of characters, each character representing a logging command.
The value set here for the 'Event Log Level' is the default for the system (i.e. all Caché servers), however you may set a different value for individual Caché Servers.

The CSP Gateway writes the Event Log to the serial file named CSP.log that is in the same directory as the CSP Gateway run-time module. You can view or clear the Event Log from the CSP Web Gateway Management menu. These logging parameters are used mainly for troubleshooting. Therefore, InterSystems recommends that you do not enable event logging unless directed by InterSystems technical support.

The 'n' parameter represents the number of seconds (total service time) below which data is not recorded for a request. For example, a directive of 'p' will record data for all requests, 'p2' will record data for all requests taking longer than 2 seconds to service.
The following information is recorded.
Total time to service request: The total time spent in servicing the request (from the time it reaches the Gateway to the time at which the last Byte of response data leaves the Gateway environment.

Obtain [NEW] connection to Caché: The time taken between the request reaching the Gateway and a connection to Caché being reserved for the purpose of servicing the request. The message recorded will indicate if a new connection is created during this time (as opposed to an existing one being reused).
Send request to Caché: The time taken between the first and last Byte of request data being read from the web server and dispatched to Caché.
Processing request in Caché: The time taken between the last Byte of request data being dispatched to Caché and the first Byte of response data being received by the Gateway.
Receive response from Caché: The time taken between the first and last Byte of response data being received from Caché and dispatched to the web server.

The set of parameters relevant to state-less connections are:
State-less Parameter

The CSP Gateway implements process affinity. This means that it will always attempt to reconnect state-less sessions to the same Caché process that serviced their previous request if possible. This parameter specifies the minimum number of connections that the CSP Gateway should make to the Caché server before starting to share the connections among many state-less clients. The higher this number, the more effective process affinity will be.

The absolute maximum number of connections that the Gateway is allowed to make to the Caché server. If concurrent usage exceeds this number, the CSP Gateway will start to queue requests. Requests will remain in the queue until a Caché connection becomes available to service the request or the 'Queued Request Timeout' is exceeded.

The following parameters are only relevant to connections to Caché v5.1 (and later) systems. These parameters represent the security settings that are required by the Gateway for the purpose of accessing the Caché server.
Security Parameter
This is the level of security required for the purpose of connecting to the Caché server. One of the following options should be selected from the list:

Password - This is the simplest form of authentication that can be applied between the Gateway and Caché. It should be remembered that Caché passwords are a weak form of authentication since they must be sent over the network as plain text for authentication in Caché. Using Kerberos to secure connections between the CSP Gateway and Caché
Windows

Kerberos key tables are not implemented for Windows. Therefore, authentication uses network credentials that are either obtained when the hosting service starts in a named account or from the Trusted Computing Base (TCB) when the hosting service runs in the System Logon Session (i.e. as "LOCAL SYSTEM").

Windows domain accounts use a permanent key derived from a password to acquire a Kerberos Ticket Granting Ticket (TGT) and service ticket for the local machine. The local machine must also have a permanent Kerberos key, shared with the Key Distribution Centre (KDC) component of the domain controller. That key can be used to acquire a TGT and service ticket to authenticate to another Kerberos principal such as Caché.

For practical purposes the Gateway, operating within the context of a Windows based web server will be operating through either the Network Service logon session or the System logon session. The account used must have "Log on as a batch job" rights assigned.

The built in Network Service logon session has access to the machines credentials and is designed for services that need network credentials to authenticate to other machines. However, the Network Service logon session is not always present. The System logon session can also be used for the purpose of authenticating the Gateway to Caché.

For IIS installations, and ISAPI extensions in particular, using the Network Service login session is the preferred means through which both databases (local and remote) and remote computers should be accessed.
The Service Principal Name should be set to that of the target Caché server that the Gateway is connecting to. The User Name, Password and Key Table fields should be left empty.
The client principal name (or client username) is that of the Gateway host. This will be the Kerberos name representing the Gateway hosts' network service session:
<computer_name>$

This principle should be assigned the necessary privileges in the Caché server for the purpose of allowing the Gateway's service to operate. It should be noted that the Gateway will automatically submit this name to Caché, it need not be explicitly defined in the Gateway configuration.
UNIX and OpenVMS
These Operating Systems support Kerberos Key Tables. The Gateway configuration is conceptually more straightforward for these systems.
The Service Principal Name should be set to that of the target Caché server that the Gateway is connecting to.
The name of the key table file (including the full path) should be entered in the Key Table field.
The User Name field should be set to the name of the appropriate principal in the key table file.
The Password field should be left empty.

The client principal name (or client username) is that of the Gateway host. This will be the name used to identify the key in the Kerberos Key Table. This principle should be assigned the necessary privileges in the Caché server for the purpose of allowing the Gateway's service to operate.

The descriptions of the Optional Parameters are the same as those given in the 'Default Parameters' section. If any of these parameters is blank, its value is inherited from the CSP Gateway's global configuration.

The 'Error Pages' parameters let you customize the CSP Gateway's responses. They are inherited from the global configuration if not specified. For more information on each parameter, see the 'Custom Error Messages' section.
Copying a Server Configuration

You can quickly configure a new server by copying the configuration entry of an existing server. At that point, both configuration entries will be identical, except for the server name. You can then edit the second configuration and make changes to it (such as changing the IP address).

This feature is also useful for fine-tuning a configuration. By creating a second (temporary) configuration for a server, you can test parameter changes without worrying about losing the original configuration.
To copy an existing server configuration:
From the CSP Web Gateway Management page, select 'Server Access'.
At the 'Server Access' screen, select an existing server name.
Check the 'Copy Server' option.
Click on the 'Submit' button. The second configuration screen appears.

Configuring Application Access
The Configure Application Access option lets you:
Configure access to your CSP applications according to the path through which you will be accessing them.
Copy a configured application path's entry to another path. This is a quick method of adding a new application path.
Disable access through a particular application path.
Delete a configured application path.
Adding Application Paths

Each CSP Application must have the paths to its CSP files configured. The configuration for each path identifies the Caché server responsible for running the application. Optional directives for specifying fail-over and load-balancing are also included in the application path's configuration. The absolute default root application path (/) is automatically configured when the CSP Gateway is started for the first time. Inheritance is applied to application paths. For example, if a CSP request asks for a file in '/Accounts/Invoices' and there is no configuration for '/Accounts/Invoices', the CSP Gateway will use the configuration defined for '/Accounts'. If this is not defined, the configuration for the absolute default path of '/' will be used.
To configure access to an application:
From the CSP Web Gateway Management page, select 'Application Access'.
Click the 'Add Application' button. The second configuration screen appears. Note that many parameter fields have default settings.
In the 'Application Path' textbox enter a unique path for the application. This path will be the path which appears in the application's URLs.
Enter the system parameters (described below) for this application path configuration.

When you have finished, click the 'Save Configuration' button. Changes you make to the application configuration will take effect as new user sessions are created for that application path. Existing users will be unaffected.
Application Path Configuration Parameters
The application configuration form contains the fields shown in the following tables. The set of base parameters are:
Allows you to enable and disable access to an application via the application's path (default is Enabled).

The physical path to the corresponding directory on the web server. This setting is particularly important for Microsoft IIS/PWS systems where each path configured must be set up as a virtual directory under the web server configuration. Each virtual directory defined within IIS/PWS must have a physical path associated with it. The purpose of this additional configuration procedure for IIS/PWS is to allow the paths used by CSP to be defined with 'execute' permissions. The default is for execute (and hence access to CSP) to be denied.

A comma-separated list of additional CGI Environment Variables to be returned to the Caché environment with each request. The commonly used CGI Environment Variables are automatically sent with each request. Enter the wildcard character (*) to instruct the CSP Gateway to send all Environment Variables supplied by the web server to the Caché environment with each request.

Process files in this path with the specified class. This allows you to build your own request handlers in CSP. For example, you could build your own WebDAV server by creating a WebDAV class and defining it here. There is a WebLink emulation class which makes use of this facility: %CSP.WebLink.
This allows you to enable or disable GZIP compression for all CSP pages returned in this path. The default setting is 'Disabled'.
This allows you to specify the minimum response size, specified in Bytes, for which GZIP compression will be invoked.

This allows you to specify whether HTTP KeepAlive connectivity should be enabled or disabled for this path. The default is 'No Action' in which case the KeepAlive status will be determined by the HTTP response headers for each request.

This allows you to specify whether the 'Non-Parsed Headers' protocol should be enabled or disabled for this path. The default is 'Enabled' in which case HTTP response headers will be streamed directly back to the client. If this property is disabled, the response headers will be submitted back to the hosting web server. This gives the web server the opportunity to parse the headers and invoke any output filters that may be indicated (For example the Apache 'mod_deflate' facility).
The set of Server parameters are:
Server Parameter
The default Caché server to which the CSP Gateway will connect for the purpose of running this application
A list of alternative Caché servers may be defined for an application. Use this parameter to check the purpose for which you want them to be used. There are three options:
Use for Load-Balancing (Fail-over is implied for this option).
Use for Fail-over only (Use the alternatives only if the main (i.e. default) server becomes unavailable).
Disabled (Do not connect to the alternative servers under any circumstances).
'#' denotes the server number

Define your list of alternative servers here. The configuration screen will only show three empty server slots at any one time, but you can define any number of alternative servers. Each alternative server can be marked as 'Enabled' or 'Disabled'. The default setting is always 'Enabled'.
Load-Balancing and Failover

Load-Balancing is implemented in a round robin fashion. Each new user session will be connected to the next available 'alternative' server (including the 'Default' Server). Once a user session is established on a server, the Gateway will endeavor to maintain the session on that server unless it becomes unavailable, in which case the session will be failed-over to the next available server in the list. State-aware sessions (preserve mode = 1) cannot be failed-over under any circumstances and, consequently, the session will be closed if the hosting server becomes unavailable.
Copying an Application Path Configuration

You can quickly configure a new application path by copying the configuration entry of an existing path. At that point, both configuration entries will be identical, except for the application path. You can then edit the second configuration and make changes to it (such as changing the Caché server).

This feature is also useful for fine-tuning a configuration. By creating a second (temporary) configuration for an application path, you can test parameter changes without worrying about losing the original configuration.
To copy an existing application path configuration:
From the CSP Web Gateway Management page, select 'Application Access'.
At the 'Application Access' screen, select an existing application path.
Check the 'Copy Application' option.
Click on the 'Submit' button. The second configuration screen appears.
In the 'Application Path' textbox, enter a new and unique application path.
Click the 'Save Configuration' button. The new application configuration will take effect as new user sessions are created for the new application path. Existing users will be unaffected.

Check the 'Edit Application' option.
Click on the 'Submit' button. The application path's configuration screen appears.
For the 'Application Status' parameter, select Disabled.
To re-enable access, repeat the procedure and select Enabled at Step 4.

Checking the System Status
The 'System Status' option displays the status of all active CSP connections. You must be a system manager to use this feature.
The First Status screen (Connections to Caché) displays the following information:
Status Field
The number that the CSP Gateway assigns to the connection. Your Caché license determines the number of possible connections.
The name of the Caché system connected to.
The IP address of the Caché system.
The TCP port on the Caché server through which the connection communicates. The default port is 1972.
The process ID on the Caché server.

Indicates if information is being sent to or from the Caché system. If this column reads 'Free', no information is being sent and the connection is ready to process the next request. If it reads 'In Use', information is being transmitted through the connection. If it reads 'Private', the connection is state-aware and not free for general use.
The number of transactions (hits) the connection has processed.
The Close button (if available) lets you forcefully close down the connection.
The Second Status screen (Caché Servers) displays the following information:
The total number of connections to the Caché system.
The total number of connections that are currently in use (i.e. actively serving a web request).
The total number of connections that are currently in use as state-aware sessions (preserve mode = 1).
The total number of transactions (hits) the Caché system has processed.

The number of web requests that are held in a queue waiting for a free connection to the Caché system. Queued requests are an indication that the Caché license should be increased in order to maintain good performance.
The Third Status screen (where applicable) displays the following information:
The number of requests queued and waiting to be processed by the NSD component.
The number of CSP forms cached by the Gateway.
The total amount of cached form data held in the Gateway (in Bytes).
The number of hits for forms held in the Gateway cache.
The Clear Cache button (if available) allows you to manually clear the Gateway form cache.
The Refresh button lets you update the status screen.

The 'Test Server Connection' option on the CSP Web Gateway Management page is useful to test CSP Gateway connectivity to your Caché systems.
Note that you must be a system manager to use this feature.
To test CSP connectivity:
From the CSP Web Gateway Management page, select 'Test Server Connection'.
Select the desired Caché system from the displayed list.
Check 'View Server-side Log' see the CSP error log on the Caché Server
Click the 'Connect' button.
Depending on your selection and the state of the server connection, you will receive one of the following results:
Connectivity Result
CSP Test Form

CSP is installed and working properly. You should receive this form if you selected State-Less Connection or State-Aware Connection. The form lists the variables (both user-defined and CGI Environment) that were passed to the server.
Server Event Log
You should receive this page if you selected View Server-side Event Log.
System Availability Error
This error occurs any time that Caché is unreachable. If there are no additional error messages, check to ensure your Caché system is running.

Closing Connections Manually
If your Caché system shuts down while a CSP connection is still active, CSP will continue to try to connect to the system until one of the following occurs:
It successfully reconnects to the system
CSP is shut down
The connection is manually closed
If your Caché system is scheduled for extensive down-time, you may want to close the connections from the 'Close Connections' option:
To close sessions manually:
From the CSP Web Gateway Management page, select 'Close Connections'.
Use the drop-down listbox to select the server from which you wish to disconnect. You can select * (asterisk) to close all connections to all servers.
Click the 'Close Connection(s)' button.
Note that you can close the connections while the Caché system is down.
